segments.en: Linked Discourses 47
1. In Ambapālī’s Wood
7. A Monkey

segments.pli: “Atthi, bhikkhave, himavato pabbatarājassa duggā visamā desā, yattha neva makkaṭānaṃ cārī na manussānaṃ.
segments.en: “Mendicants, in the Himalayas there are regions that are rugged and impassable. In some such regions, neither monkeys nor humans can go,

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, himavato pabbatarājassa duggā visamā desā, yattha makkaṭānañhi kho cārī, na manussānaṃ.
segments.en: while in others, monkeys can go but not humans.

segments.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, himavato pabbatarājassa samā bhūmibhāgā ramaṇīyā, yattha makkaṭānañceva cārī manussānañca.
segments.en: There are also level, pleasant places where both monkeys and humans can go.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, luddā makkaṭavīthīsu lepaṃ oḍḍenti makkaṭānaṃ bādhanāya.
segments.en: There hunters lay snares of tar on the monkey trails to catch the monkeys.

segments.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te makkaṭā abālajātikā alolajātikā, te taṃ lepaṃ disvā ārakā parivajjanti.
segments.en: The monkeys who are not foolhardy and reckless see the tar and avoid it from afar.

segments.pli: Yo pana so hoti makkaṭo bālajātiko lolajātiko, so taṃ lepaṃ upasaṅkamitvā hatthena gaṇhāti.
segments.en: But a foolish and reckless monkey goes up to the tar and grabs it with a hand.
He gets stuck there.
Thinking to free his hand, he grabs it with his other hand.
He gets stuck there.
Thinking to free both hands, he grabs it with a foot.
He gets stuck there.

segments.pli: ‘Ubho hatthe mocessāmi pādañcā’ti dutiyena pādena gaṇhāti.
segments.en: Thinking to free both hands and foot, he grabs it with his other foot.
He gets stuck there.

segments.pli: ‘Ubho hatthe mocessāmi pāde cā’ti tuṇḍena gaṇhāti.
segments.en: Thinking to free both hands and feet, he grabs it with his snout.
He gets stuck there.

segments.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, makkaṭo pañcoḍḍito thunaṃ seti anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo luddassa.
segments.en: And so the monkey, trapped at five points, just lies there screeching. He’d meet with tragedy and disaster, and the hunter can do what he wants with him.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, luddo vijjhitvā tasmiṃyeva kaṭṭhakataṅgāre avassajjetvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
segments.en: The hunter spears him, pries him off that tarred block of wood, and goes wherever he wants.

segments.pli: Evaṃ so taṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yo agocare carati paravisaye.
segments.en: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, mā agocare carittha paravisaye.
segments.en: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.

segments.pli: Agocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ paravisaye lacchati māro otāraṃ, lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
segments.en: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will catch you and get hold of you.

segments.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo?
segments.en: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?
It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
What five?

segments.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
segments.en: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
Sounds known by the ear …
Smells known by the nose …
Tastes known by the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
segments.en: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.

segments.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
segments.en: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.

segments.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ sake pettike visaye na lacchati māro otāraṃ, na lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
segments.en: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t catch you or get hold of you.

segments.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo?
segments.en: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?
It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
What four?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo”ti.
segments.en: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”

sections.title: “Mendicants, in the Himalayas there are regions that are…

suttaplex.blurb: The parable of the foolish monkey who gets trapped in tar when it ventures outside its ancestral territory. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
